sn22.154:1.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does wrong view arise?”
sn22.154:1.3: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn22.154:1.4: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, wrong view arises.
sn22.154:1.8: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, wrong view arises.
sn22.154:1.13: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would wrong view arise?”
sn22.154:1.20: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.154:1.22: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would wrong view arise?”
sn22.154:1.25: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
